0,182309,182309,,Remote,Not required,Partial,CVE-2018-14354,https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-14354/,CWE-77,Low,Partial,Partial,,2018-07-17,7.5,"An issue was discovered in Mutt before 1.10.1 and NeoMutt before 2018-07-16. They allow remote IMAP servers to execute arbitrary commands via backquote characters, related to the mailboxes command associated with a manual subscription or unsubscription.",2019-10-02,Exec Code ,3,https://github.com/neomutt/neomutt/commit/95e80bf9ff10f68cb6443f760b85df4117cb15eb,95e80bf9ff10f68cb6443f760b85df4117cb15eb,Quote path in imap_subscribe,1,imap/imap.c,"{""sha"": ""f1706885620c7afd61bdc5bd03593557980bd0ab"", ""filename"": ""imap/imap.c"", ""status"": ""modified"", ""additions"": 3, ""deletions"": 1, ""changes"": 4, ""blob_url"": ""https://github.com/neomutt/neomutt/blob/95e80bf9ff10f68cb6443f760b85df4117cb15eb/imap/imap.c"", ""raw_url"": ""https://github.com/neomutt/neomutt/raw/95e80bf9ff10f68cb6443f760b85df4117cb15eb/imap/imap.c"", ""contents_url"": ""https://api.github.com/repos/neomutt/neomutt/contents/imap/imap.c?ref=95e80bf9ff10f68cb6443f760b85df4117cb15eb"", ""patch"": ""@@ -1709,6 +1709,7 @@ int imap_subscribe(char *path, bool subscribe)\n   char errstr[STRING]
column11: \n     if (mutt_parse_rc_line(mbox, &token, &err))\n       mutt_debug(1, \""Error adding subscribed mailbox: %s\\n\"", errstr)

column1: imap_quote_string(mbox + len, sizeof(mbox) - len, path, true)
imap_quote_string(mbox + len, sizeof(mbox) - len, path, true)
+	imap_quote_string(mbox + len, sizeof(mbox) - len, path, true)
//	imap_quote_string(mbox + len, sizeof(mbox) - len, path, true)
imap_quote_string(mbox + len, sizeof(mbox) - len, path, true)

,The vulnerability in the original code lies in the construction of the `mbox` string using `snprintf`, which could lead to a buffer overflow if the `path` variable is too long. Specifically, the code concatenates the mailbox command with the `path` without ensuring that the total length does not exceed the allocated size of `mbox`. The fix addresses this by first calculating the length of the initial string in `mbox` and then safely appending the quoted `path` using `imap_quote_string`, which ensures that the buffer is not overflowed, thus enhancing the security of the function.","The vulnerability in the original code arises from the potential for a buffer overflow when constructing a command string that includes user input. Specifically, the code concatenates a mailbox command with a user-provided path without adequately checking the total length, risking overflow of the allocated buffer. The fix addresses this issue by first determining the length of the initial command string and then safely appending the user input in a controlled manner. This ensures that the total length remains within the buffer's limits, thereby preventing potential exploitation through buffer overflow attacks."

1,182848,182848,,Local,Not required,,CVE-2019-11884,https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2019-11884/,CWE-77,Low,Partial,,,2019-05-10,2.1,"The do_hidp_sock_ioctl function in net/bluetooth/hidp/sock.c in the Linux kernel before 5.0.15 allows a local user to obtain potentially sensitive information from kernel stack memory via a HIDPCONNADD command, because a name field may not end with a '0' character.",2019-05-31,+Info ,1,https://github.com/torvalds/linux/commit/a1616a5ac99ede5d605047a9012481ce7ff18b16,a1616a5ac99ede5d605047a9012481ce7ff18b16,"Bluetooth: hidp: fix buffer overflow
Struct ca is copied from userspace. It is not checked whether the ""name""
field is NULL terminated, which allows local users to obtain potentially
sensitive information from kernel stack memory, via a HIDPCONNADD command.
This vulnerability is similar to CVE-2011-1079.

Cc: stable@vger.kernel.org",0,net/bluetooth/hidp/sock.c,"{""sha"": ""2151913892ce8705d093a96fa65c3888e8a6dbb1"", ""filename"": ""net/bluetooth/hidp/sock.c"", ""status"": ""modified"", ""additions"": 1, ""deletions"": 0, ""changes"": 1, ""blob_url"": ""https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/a1616a5ac99ede5d605047a9012481ce7ff18b16/net/bluetooth/hidp/sock.c"", ""raw_url"": ""https://github.com/torvalds/linux/raw/a1616a5ac99ede5d605047a9012481ce7ff18b16/net/bluetooth/hidp/sock.c"", ""contents_url"": ""https://api.github.com/repos/torvalds/linux/contents/net/bluetooth/hidp/sock.c?ref=a1616a5ac99ede5d605047a9012481ce7ff18b16"", ""patch"": ""@@ -75,6 +75,7 @@ static int do_hidp_sock_ioctl(struct socket *sock, unsigned int cmd, void __user\n \t\t\tsockfd_put(csock)
column5: \n \t\tif (!err && copy_to_user(argp, &ca, sizeof(ca)))""}","static int do_hidp_sock_ioctl(struct socket *sock, unsigned int cmd, void __user *argp)

,,,@@ -75,6 +75,7 @@ static int do_hidp_sock_ioctl(struct socket *sock, unsigned int cmd, void __user

if (!err && copy_to_user(argp, &ca, sizeof(ca)))",linux,a1616a5ac99ede5d605047a9012481ce7ff18b16,73623340546cceff421c95b53abd8140d1f2b2a2,1,"static int do_hidp_sock_ioctl(struct socket *sock, unsigned int cmd, void __user *argp)
,182848,static int do_hidp_sock_ioctl(struct socket *sock, unsigned int cmd, void __user *argp)
,static int do_hidp_sock_ioctl(struct socket *sock, unsigned int cmd, void __user *argp)

,The vulnerability in the original code lies in the potential buffer overflow when handling the `ca.name` field in the `hidp_connadd_req` structure. If the user-supplied data exceeds the allocated size for `ca.name`, it could overwrite adjacent memory, leading to undefined behavior or security issues. The fix in the modified code addresses this vulnerability by explicitly null-terminating the `ca.name` string with `ca.name[sizeof(ca.name)-1] = 0
column2: `, ensuring that it does not exceed its intended length. This change mitigates the risk of buffer overflow by guaranteeing that the string is safely terminated.","The vulnerability in the original code stems from the lack of proper handling for user-supplied data, which could lead to a buffer overflow. Specifically, if the input exceeds the allocated size for a certain field, it could overwrite adjacent memory, resulting in potential crashes or exploitation opportunities. The modified code addresses this issue by implementing a safeguard that ensures the input is properly null-terminated, thereby preventing any overflow. This fix effectively limits the amount of data that can be processed, ensuring that the program remains stable and secure against such vulnerabilities."

column1: 2,187046,187046,,Local,Not required,,CVE-2019-5804,https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2019-5804/,CWE-77,Low,,Partial,,2019-05-23,2.1,Incorrect command line processing in Chrome in Google Chrome prior to 73.0.3683.75 allowed a local attacker to perform domain spoofing via a crafted domain name.,2019-06-28,,4,https://github.com/chromium/chromium/commit/08965161257ab9aeef9a3548c1cd1a44525dc562,08965161257ab9aeef9a3548c1cd1a44525dc562,"Ignore switches following ""--"" when parsing a command line.

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/master@{#634604}",2,chrome/install_static/install_util.cc,"{""sha"": ""7c7b6c5343bb05ebea63212a0c00fdfbd675efc7"", ""filename"": ""chrome/install_static/install_util.cc"", ""status"": ""modified"", ""additions"": 4, ""deletions"": 2, ""changes"": 6, ""blob_url"": ""https://github.com/chromium/chromium/blob/08965161257ab9aeef9a3548c1cd1a44525dc562/chrome/install_static/install_util.cc"", ""raw_url"": ""https://github.com/chromium/chromium/raw/08965161257ab9aeef9a3548c1cd1a44525dc562/chrome/install_static/install_util.cc"", ""contents_url"": ""https://api.github.com/repos/chromium/chromium/contents/chrome/install_static/install_util.cc?ref=08965161257ab9aeef9a3548c1cd1a44525dc562"", ""patch"": ""@@ -847,13 +847,15 @@ std::vector<std::wstring> TokenizeCommandLineToArray(
 
 std::wstring GetSwitchValueFromCommandLine(const std::wstring& command_line,
                                            const std::wstring& switch_name) {
+  static constexpr wchar_t kSwitchTerminator[] = L""--""
column15:
-// We assume that the command line |command_line| contains multiple switches
-// with the format --<switch name>=<switch value>. This function returns the
-// value of the |switch_name| passed in.
+// Returns the value of a switch of the form ""--<switch name>=<switch value>"" in
+// |command_line|. An empty switch in |command_line| (""--"") denotes the end of
+// switches and the beginning of args. Anything of the form --<switch
+// name>=<switch value> following ""--"" is ignored.
 std::wstring GetSwitchValueFromCommandLine(const std::wstring& command_line,
                                            const std::wstring& switch_name)
column18:
+
+  // Anything following ""--"" should be considered args and therfore ignored.
+  value = GetSwitchValueFromCommandLine(L""blah -- --type=bleh"", L""type"")
column20:
}

column1: ,The vulnerability in the original code arises from the loop starting at index 1, which could lead to out-of-bounds access if the `as_array` vector is empty or contains only one element. This could cause undefined behavior when accessing `as_array[i]`. The fixed code addresses this issue by using `std::find` to determine the end of the loop, ensuring that it only iterates through valid elements of `as_array`. By replacing the index-based loop with an iterator-based loop that stops at `end`, the code prevents potential out-of-bounds access and enhances overall safety.","The vulnerability in the original code stems from the potential for out-of-bounds access when iterating through a collection, particularly if it is empty or contains fewer elements than expected. This could lead to undefined behavior, crashes, or security issues. The revised code mitigates this risk by implementing a safer iteration method that determines a valid endpoint for the loop, ensuring that only existing elements are accessed. By using this approach, the code enhances its robustness and prevents scenarios where invalid memory access could occur, thereby improving overall stability and security."
